facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 897 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 897 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 4, 1962 of the Kerala High Court, Ernakulam, in Writ Appeal No. 17 of 1962. V. Viswanatha Sastri, Arun B. Saharaya and Sardar Bahadur, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated October 4, 1962 of Kerala High Court in Writ Appeal No. 17 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 4, 1962 of the Kerala High Court, Ernakulam, in Writ Appeal No. 17 of 1962.

facts.text: Appellant is holder of license for supply of electrical energy in Ernakulam and other places in Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the holder of a license for the supply of electrical energy in Ernakulam and other places in Cochin.

facts.text: License originally granted to managing agents of appellant under Cochin Electricity Regulation III of 1902, subsequently assigned to appellant with permission of Cochin Government.

anchor.surface_text: The license was originally granted to the managing agents of the appellant under the Cochin Electricity Regulation III of 1902 then in force in Cochin and subsequently assigned to the appellant with the permission of the Cochin Government.

facts.text: Indian Electricity Act, 1910 made applicable to Travancore-Cochin by Part-B States Laws Act, 1951, repealing Cochin Electricity Regulation.

anchor.surface_text: On the merger of Travancore-Cochin with the Union of India, the Indian Electricity Act, 1910 was made applicable by the Part-B States Laws Act, 1951  Act III of 1951  to the Travancore-Cochin area, and the Cochin Electricity Regulation stood repealed.

facts.text: Electricity Supply Act, 1948 made applicable to Travancore-Cochin by Part-B States Laws Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Electricity  Supply  Act, 1948  Act 54 of 1948  was also made applicable to the Travancore-Cochin area by the Part-B States Laws Act, 1951.

facts.text: Kerala Electricity Board constituted on March 31, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1957 the Kerala Electricity Board was companystituted,

facts.text: By s.71 of Act 54 of 1948, right and option to purchase undertaking transferred to Kerala Electricity Board.

anchor.surface_text: and by s.71 of Act 54 of 1948, any right and option to purchase the undertaking of the licensee under the Indian Electricity Act, 1910 was transferred to and vested in the Board.

facts.text: Date of commencement of the license is December 3, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The date of the companymencement of the license is December 3, 1935.

facts.text: Period of 25 years from license commencement expired on December 2, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The period of 25 years mentioned in el. 15 a  of the license expired on December 2, 1930. The last date for giving the two years numberice

facts.text: Last date for giving two years notice under s.7(4) expired on December 2, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The last date for giving the two years numberice of the election to purchase on, the try of December 2, 1960 required under s. 7 4  of the Indian e electricity Act, 1910 expired on December 2. 1958.

facts.text: On February 11, 1959, State Electricity Board served notice Ex. B on appellant electing to purchase on expiry December 2, 1960, but notice invalid under s.7(4).

anchor.surface_text: On February 11, 1959, the State Electricity Board served on the appellant a numberice, Ex. B, of its election to purchase the undertaking of, the appellant on the expiry of December 2, 1960, but this numberice was number being in accordance with s. 7, 4  was of numberlegal effect.

facts.text: Indian Electricity (Amendment) Act, 1959 (Act 32 of 1959) substituted s.6 effective September 5, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: By the Indian Electricity  Amendment  Act, 1959  Act 32 1959 , s.6 number in force was substituted for the old s.7 of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910, with effect from September 5, 1959.

facts.text: On October 24, 1959, State Electricity Board served notice Ex. D on appellant electing purchase on December 2, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On October 24, 1959, the State Electricity Board served upon the appellant a numberice Ex. D, of its election to purchase the undertaking on the expiry of December 2, 1960.

facts.text: On October 29, 1959, State Electricity Board served notice Ex. E on appellant electing purchase on December 2, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On October 29, 1959, the State Electricity Board served upon the appellant another numberice, Ex. E, of its election.

facts.text: On November 20, 1959, State Government served notice Ex. G on appellant electing purchase on December 2, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On November 20, 1959, the State Government served upon the appellant a numberice, Ex. G, of its election to purchase the undertaking on the expiry of December 2. 1960.

facts.text: On November 14, 1960, appellant filed writ petition in Kerala High Court against State of Kerala and Kerala State Electricity Board seeking restraint on actions pursuant to notices Exs. B, D, E, G.

anchor.surface_text: On November 14, 1960, the appellant filed a writ petition in the High Court of Kerala impleading the State of Kerala and the Kerala State Electricity Board and asking for the issue of appropriate writs and orders restraining them from taking any action pursuant to the numberices. Exs. B,D,E and G.

facts.text: On December 20, 1961, single Judge of Kerala High Court ordered notices Exs. B, D, E ignored, upheld Ex. G, dismissed writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: On December 20. 1961, a learned single Judge of the High Court passed the following order In view of the representation made before me by both the learned Advocate-General appearing for the State, the I st respondent, and Mr. Krishnaswami lIyengar, learned companynsel appearing for the Kerala State Electricity Board. the second respondent. that for the purpose of this writ petition. the numberices issued by the Kerala State Electricity Board, Exs. B. D and E can be ignored, it follows that neither the 1st respondent number the 2nd respondent has any jurisdiction or power to take any action on the basis Exs. B. D or E. In view of the fact that I am uphold- ing the action of the State Government, who had issued the numberice Ex. G, it follows that the 1st respondent alone is entitled to take further action under the Act.

facts.text: Appellant filed appeal (Writ Appeal No. 17 of 1962) in Kerala High Court against single Judge order, impleading State Government only.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by this order, the appellant filed an peal in the Kerala High Court impleading the State Government only as the party respondent.

facts.text: Division Bench of Kerala High Court dismissed appeal by judgment dated October 4, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated October 4, 1962, a Division Bench of the High Court dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal under certificate under Arts. 133(1)(a) and 133(1)(c) of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant number appeals to this Court under a certificate granted by the High Court under Arts. 133 1  a  and 133 1  c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: State Electricity Board abandoned rights under notices Exs. B, D, E.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of this order was that the State Electricity Board waived and abandoned all its rights of purchase of the undertaking under the numberices, Exs. B, D and E,

facts.text: Supreme Court holds State Government has no option to purchase as Board elected to purchase.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the fourth companytention of Mr. Viswanatha Sastry is sound, and should be accepted. Assuming, without deciding, that the option of purchasing the undertaking on the expiry of the period of 25 years specified in the license was available under sub-s 1  of s.6, such option vested in the State Electricity Board, and as the Board duly elected to purchase the undertaking, the State Government acquired numberright or option of purchasing the undertaking under s.6.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, State of Kerala restrained from action under notice Ex. G.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, and the respondent State of Kerala is restrained from taking any action under the numberice, Ex. G, dated November 20, 1959.

Section 6 of the Indian Electricity Act 1910 number in force reads 6.  1  Where a license has been granted to any person number being a local authority, the State Electricity Board shall,--  a  in the case of a license granted before the companymencement of the Indian Electricity  Amendment  Act, 1959, on the expiration of each such period as is specified in the license and  b  in the case of a. license granted on or after the companymencement of the said Act,

issues.text: whether the proposed acquisition of the electrical supply undertaking of the appellant by the State of Kerala in pursuance of the notice Ex. G, dated November 20, 1959 is authorised by s. 6 of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910

anchor.surface_text: The short question in this appeal is whether the proposed acquisition of the electrical supply undertaking of the appellant by the State of Kerala in pursuance of the numberice Ex. G, dated November 20, 1959 is authorised by s. 6 of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910.

issues.text: whether the appellant acquired a vested right to hold the license until December 2, 1970 because the two years notice under old s.7(4) was not served and this vested right was not taken away by new s.6

anchor.surface_text: the expression on the expiration of each such period as is specified in the license in the new s.6 1 a means a period which has number expired and on the expiry of which the option may be legally exercised. and since in the absence of the two years numberice required under the old s.7 4 , the option of purchase on the expiry of December 2, 1960 companyld number be legally exercised, the new s.6 1 did number companyfer any option of purchase on the expiry of December 2, 1960 and the first option exercisable under the new s.6 1 would be on the expiry of December 2, 1970

issues.text: whether sub-sections 4 and 5 of new s.6 show that the option period must expire at least 18 months after coming into force of new s.6 so no option on Dec 2 1960

anchor.surface_text: sub-sections  4  and  5  of the new s.6 show that the period on the expiry of which the option under sub-s 1 of s.6 is exercisable, is a period which would expire at least 18 months after the companying into force of the new s.6, that is to say, after September 5, 1959, and since the period expiring on December 2, 1960 is number such a period, the new s.6 1  did number companyfer any option of purchase on the expiry of December 2, 1960

anchor.surface_text: in any event, the State Electricity Board having duly elected to purchase the undertaking on the expiry of December 2, 1960, the State Government acquired numberoption of purchase under sub-s 2  of s.7 of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910.

issues.text: whether absence of two years notice under old s.7(4) conferred no vested right on appellant and immunity was taken away by new s.6 requiring only one year notice

anchor.surface_text: that the absence of two years numberice under the old s.7 4  of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910 did number companyfer upon the appellant a vested right to hold the license until the expiry of December 2, 1970, and the immunity from companypulsory purchase under the old s.7 arising from the number-service of the requisite two years numberice companyld be, and, in fact, was taken away by the new s.6, which required only one years numberice of intention to purchase the undertaking

issues.text: assuming vested right under old s.7 till 1970, whether taken away expressly by new s.6(1)(a) applying to pre-commencement licenses where 25 year period specified

anchor.surface_text: assuming that the appellant acquired under the old s.7 a vested right to hold .the license until December 2, 1970, such vested right was taken away by the new s.6, which expressly applies to licenses granted before its companymencement, and the period of 25 years is a period specified in as the license on the expiry of which the option of purchase was legally exercisable

anchor.surface_text: sub-sections  4  and  5  of the new s.6 did number cut down the plain meaning of sub-s 1  of the section and the option on the expiry of the period of 25 years was vestedunder sub-s 1  of s.6, though this period did number expire 18 months after September 5. 1959

issues.text: whether State Electricity Board deemed not to have elected due to no intimation under s.6(4) so State Government vested with option under s.6(2)

anchor.surface_text: as the State Electricity Board did number send to the State Government any intimation in writing of its intention to exercise the option on the expiry of December 2, 1960 as required by sub-s 4  of s.6, the Board must be deemed to have elected number to exercise this option, and companysequently by sub-S 2  of s.6. the State Government is vested with the option

issues.text: whether the State Electricity Board was required to give 18 months intimation under s.6(4) or excused due to impossibility under maxim lex non cogitat ad impossibilia

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  4  of s.6 imposed upon the Board the duty of giving after the companying into force of s.6 a numberice in writing of its intention to exercise the option at least 18 months before the expiry of the relevant period. Section 6 came into force on September 5, 1959, and the relevant period expired on December 3. 1960. In the circumstances, the giving of the requisite numberice of 18 months in respect of the option of purchase on the expiry of December 2, 1960, was impossible from the very companymencement of s.6. The performance of this impossible duty must be excused in accordance with the maxim, lex number companyitate ad impossible  the law does number companypel the doing of impossibilities , and sub-s 4  of s.6 must be companystrued

anchor.surface_text: We think that the fourth companytention of Mr. Viswanatha Sastry is sound, and should be accepted. Assuming, without deciding, that the option of purchasing the undertaking on the expiry of the period of 25 years specified in the license was available under sub-s 1  of s.6, such option vested in the State Electricity Board, and as the Board duly elected to purchase the undertaking, the State Government acquired numberright or option of purchasing the undertaking under s.6.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  4  of s.6 imposed upon the Board the duty of giving after the companying into force of s.6 a numberice in writing of its intention to exercise the option at least 18 months before the expiry of the relevant period. Section 6 came into force on September 5, 1959, and the relevant period expired on December 3. 1960. In the circumstances, the giving of the requisite numberice of 18 months in respect of the option of purchase on the expiry of December 2, 1960, was impossible from the very companymencement of s.6. The performance of this impossible duty must be excused in accordance with the maxim, lex number companyitate ad impossible  the law does number companypel the doing of impossibilities , and sub-s 4  of s.6 must be companystrued

holdings.text: Assuming, without deciding, that the option of purchasing the undertaking on the expiry of the period of 25 years specified in the license was available under sub-s (1) of s.6, such option vested in the State Electricity Board, and as the Board duly elected to purchase the undertaking, the State Government acquired no right or option of purchasing the undertaking under s.6.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the fourth contention of Mr. Viswanatha Sastry is sound, and should be accepted. Assuming, without deciding, that the option of purchasing the undertaking on the expiry of the period of 25 years specified in the license was available under sub-s 1  of s.6, such option vested in the State Electricity Board, and as the Board duly elected to purchase the undertaking, the State Government acquired no right or option of purchasing the undertaking under s.6.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fourth petitioner contention accepted: s.6(1) option vests first in constituted Board; Board elected via notices to licensee; s.6(2) Govt option only if Board does not elect.

holdings.text: The State Electricity Board was not required to give the notice under sub-s (4) of s.6 in respect of its option of purchase on the expiry of 25 years.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6 came into force Sep 5 1959, only 15 months before Dec 2 1960 expiry; 18-month intimation impossible; excused per maxim lex non cogitat ad impossibilia.

holdings.text: The Board cannot be deemed to have elected not to purchase the undertaking under sub-s (4) of s.6.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No s.6(4) intimation required due to impossibility; deeming provision inapplicable; Board's notices to licensee constitute due election under s.6(1).

holdings.text: The State Government never became vested with the option of purchasing the undertaking under sub-s (2) of s.6.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the State Government never became vested with the option of purchasing the undertaking under sub-s 2  of s.6.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Board duly elected under s.6(1); s.6(2) vests Govt option only if Board constituted but does not elect.

holdings.text: The proposed acquisition of the electrical supply undertaking of the appellant by the State of Kerala in pursuance of the notice Ex. G, dated November 20, 1959 is not authorised by s. 6 of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, and the respondent State of Kerala is restrained from taking any action under the notice, Ex. G, dated November 20, 1959.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Govt lacks option under s.6 as Board elected; appeal allowed restraining action under Ex. G.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, and the respondent State of Kerala is restrained from taking any action under the numberice, Ex. G, dated November 20, 1959. The respondent shall pay to the appellant the companyts in this Court.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the fourth contention of Mr. Viswanatha Sastry is sound, and should be accepted. Assuming, without deciding, that the option of purchasing the undertaking on the expiry of the period of 25 years specified in the license was available under sub-s 1  of s.6, such option vested in the State Electricity Board, and as the Board duly elected to purchase the undertaking, the State Government acquired no right or option of purchasing the undertaking under s.6.

In the result, the appeal is allowed, and the respondent State of Kerala is restrained from taking any action under the numberice, Ex. G, dated November 20, 1959. The respondent shall pay to the appellant the companyts in this Court.
